Exercise

In an LR circuit with applied voltage \(E = {@g@}\), the current \(i\) is given by

\[L\frac{\mathrm{d}i}{\mathrm{d}t} + Ri = {@g@}.\]

If the initial current is \(i_0\), find \(i\) subsequently.

\(i(t) = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
This is a linear differential equation that is not in standard form.

\[L\frac{\mathrm{d}i}{\mathrm{d}t} + Ri = {@g@}\]

We must first convert it to standard form by dividing both sides by \(L\). Note that here \(f(t) = R/L\) and \(\displaystyle g(t) = {@g / L@}\).

\[\frac{\mathrm{d}i}{\mathrm{d}t} + \frac{R}{L}i = {@g / L@}.\]

We use the key point to find the integrating factor:

\[\text{I.F.} = \exp \left[ \int f(t) \,\mathrm{d}t \right] = {@IF@}\]

Next we transform the equation into exact form by multiplying both sides with the integrating factor. It becomes:

\[{@IF@} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{d}i}{\mathrm{d}t} + \frac{R}{L} {@IF@} \cdot i = {@IF@} \cdot \left({@g / L@}\right)\]

Note that the left-hand side is the derivative of \({@IF@} \cdot i\) with respect to \(t\). Our equation then becomes:

\[\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t} \left( {@IF@} \cdot i \right) = {@IF * g / L@}\]

Therefore, we can find an expression for \({@IF@} \cdot i\) by integrating the right-hand side. The result is:

\[{@IF@} \cdot i = {@I@}\]

Which then gives the following general solution:

\[i = {@gsol@}\]

We can now solve for \(C\) and use the given boundary conditions:

\[C = {@Cexp@}\] \[i(0) = i_0 \implies C = {@C0@}\]

This gives the particular solution we seek:

\[i(t) = {@ta@}\]
